title: East Africa: Kenyan and Rwandan Currencies Gain As Region's Import Bill Swells
text:
The National Bank of Rwanda "increased its intervention in volume and frequency, containing the speculation and stabilising the franc," said Doreen Makumi, corporate communications officer at BNR. 
READ: Kigali faces tough task ahead in shielding franc 
ALSO READ: Falling Rwandan franc hurting importers as cost of goods soars 
Mid-last week, Kenya's Central Bank's Monetary Policy Committee surprised the markets by holding the rate at 11.50 per cent, beating off market expectations of a rate increase. 
Dr Patrick Njoroge, Central Bank Governor, said the volatility in the shilling exchange rate witnessed early last month had stabilised, indicating the increase in the Central Bank rate (CBR) from 8.5 per cent over the previous two months was now paying off. 
"Open market operations and the sale of foreign exchange by the central bank have stemmed the volatility and resulted in tight liquidity conditions with the interbank interest rate rising above the CBR," Dr Njoroge said. 
The tightening policy by Kenya has seen the interbank lending rate rise to 23 per cent from last week's opening of 18 per cent, showing that it's now costlier to hold dollars, hence the slight support to the shilling. 
George Bodo, the head of financials at Eco Bank Capital, said the move could have been informed by the fact that the shilling has been slightly gaining in the last few days. 
"We have seen slight gains of the shilling from its former position of 104 units to the current stance of 101 units. This could mean that the Central Bank's tools are working," Mr Bodo said. 
Commercial banks in Kenya quoted the shilling at 101.13 units to the dollar at the close of trade last week, a weaker position from the post-US President Barack Obama visit, during which the shilling managed to touch the 100-unit mark. 
The end-month dollar demand from energy sector importers, who are seeking foreign currency to pay their import bills, saw the shilling weaken further but this has eased even as the Central Bank spent close to $3 million last week on a mopping up exercise. 
The gain, however, is only in Kenya with the other regional currencies experiencing a slump throughout the year due to an increased import bill, weak exports and other geopolitical factors. 
Tanzania's shilling has shed 21.2 per cent with Uganda's losing 20.6 per cent. The shilling is trading at close to 3-1/2 year lows and down 11.5 per cent against the dollar this year, although the central bank has hiked rates 3 percentage points since June. 
Last month, Tanzania hinted at introduction of monetary policies as a tool to save the weakening shilling. The country is the only one in the region that has been depending on fiscal policy as an intervention method to cushion its currency. Tanzania has seen its shilling struggle further during the second quarter of 2015, moving from 1,788 units to 2,107 units per dollar as at the start of this month. 
The rising import bill has seen regional currencies lose their competitive edge against the dollar even as the exports earnings remain weak. All the East Africa nations have seen their import bill rise, dimming hopes of bridging the deficit gap. 
For instance, Kenya's import bill has increased to $8.6 billion dollars this year on account of increased inflows of industrial supplies and petroleum products compared with $7.9 billion over the same period last year. 
The Ugandan shilling is currently trading at 3,495/3,505 due to high demand by private companies paying for clients' imports. Uganda has raised its base lending rate from 12 per cent to 14.5 per cent in the last four months to tighten liquidity in the market. 
Faisal Bukenya, head of market making at Barclays Bank, said that the dollar inflow into the market is low with the little getting in being snapped up by dealers, explaining the pressure. 
"The demand for the dollar is at a high amid an increased local currency liquidity. This is keeping up the pressure on the local unit as everyone is out to get the dollar," Mr Bukenya said. East Africa
